Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Expanding CCB FEST - Community College Biology Faculty Enhancement through Scientific Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In a collaborative project involving San Francisco State University and the Foothill-DeAnza Community College District, Summer Teaching Institutes continue to be offered to community-college faculty of the San Francisco Bay area. These institutes introduce faculty to the concepts and attitudes of scientific teaching and provide professional development for faculty to change their practices to include goal setting and assessment to determine whether the goals have been met. In this expanded second stage of the project, a second Advanced Summer Institute is available to graduates of the first who are interested in collaborating to develop a common assessment tool. This tool applied to the population of San Francisco area community college students generates powerful data measuring the effectiveness of scientific teaching on student learning. Additional activities of the emerging learning community include Teaching Squares, groups of four faculty at one or several institutions who meet together regularly to share teaching strategies and observe each others' classes; and Classroom Partnerships between a mentor community college faculty member and a SFSU graduate student interested in pursuing college-level teaching as a career. The enthusiastic response to the first phase of this project demanded that it be extended and amplified. To do so in the direction of establishing data on effectiveness makes the experience all the richer. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts toward Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To address complex societal challenges such as food insecurity, energy management, and disease, the biological sciences must engage diverse populations of individuals, especially undergraduate students who will become voting citizens and some of whom will pursue professions in the biological sciences. Since the vast majority of first-generation college-going students and students of color experience some of their undergraduate biology learning in community colleges, improvement of biology teaching and learning in these institutions is key. Through this NSF Transforming Undergraduate Education in the Sciences  (TUES)  Phase 2 award, leaders from Foothill College and San Francisco State University have collaborated to expand the successful multi-pronged CCB FEST – Community College Biology Faculty Enhancement through Scientific Teaching – effort that had previously demonstrated positive outcomes in promoting enhanced faculty pedagogical expertise and in developing a community college biology instructor professional learning community.  With this new effort, CCB FEST has expanded and engaged more than a third of the community college biology faculty in the San Francisco Bay Area across 24 institutions. Through participation in pedagogical workshops, scientific teaching institutes, and multiple faculty learning community models, these community college biology instructors have collaborated to measure student learning gains, develop novel measures to gauge the extent of implementation of active learning in their classrooms, and investigated the nature of non-content language used in biology classrooms.  These iterative and collaborative efforts have resulted in multiple high profile scholarly publications, which included community college instructors as co-authors. Importantly, these efforts have also trained multiple postdoctoral fellows and graduate students who have gone on to occupy key leadership positions as biology educators in public and private universities, community colleges, museums, and curriculum development groups and who occupy professional roles as instructors, researchers, and pedagogical professional development specialists. Finally, this award has allowed leaders at both Foothill College and San Francisco State University to adapt the CCB FEST faculty professional development models serve new communities. Professor Jeffrey Schinske has extended this work to build a network of community college biology educators engaged in educational research, and Professor Kimberly Tanner has adapted these professional development models to engage over 90% of her own biology department faculty in pedagogical change. As such, the success and productivity of the initial effort has nucleated new collaborations in biology education more broadly.
